job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Middletown, CT
pros: - Middlesex has the potential to be an incredible independent organization. It has dedicated bedside staff, multiple satellite EDs, and has acquired numerous specialty groups to provide services directly, which should support long-term stability. - Nurses at Middlesex have more clout than in non-Magnet hospitals, even if the nurse-driven luster of Magnet has faded. - Many fringe benefits, like free parking in an adjacent garage on the off shifts and a year-end bonus. -You'll love the people you work with, but you'll be disappointed by the people you work for.
cons: Management is either unaware of how dire the staffing and acuity situation is, or is silent about their attempts to address the ongoing problems. Either way, it's a failure of leadership. There's a whole lot of "administrators" but not a lot of "leaders."

review_title: One of the most reputable paramedic programs in the state.
pros: The Middlesex Hospital Paramedics have more autonomy then any other paramedic position. No other paramedic employers have the shift differentials Middlesex offers. It is a high call volume environment, sometimes with long transport times, ideal to get excellent patient care experience. They only respond to 911 calls. Because it is a small group, they have better quality control and therefore, have more liberal protocols with virtually everything on standing order, including RSI. It also means they can be selective in who they hire. The group are highly skilled professionals. Current medical control is top notch.
cons: Not really a con but often people don't expect the other responsibilities that come with the job. The department is very self sufficient. On of the challenges people often find is the logistics of the system, deciding on which hospital to transport to and how it will affect the system.

review_title: Honestly, a very nice place to work as a Registered Nurse
pros: Management and staff have very high standards. Patient assignments are generally based on acuity. Med/surg and similar units have a maximum of 1:5 ratio. Great continuing education opportunities. This is a Magnet Hospital so attaining your BSN is promoted (if not required of new hires because it definitely is of new grads who are hired into their graduate nurse internship program). Specialty certification is also strongly supported. In general the staff are very professional and caring. 8 hour shifts are readily available in most areas
cons: Units vary. The medical unit tends to be a dumping ground but telemetry, oncology and surgery are well managed and have very high levels of nursing satisfaction.

review_title: Very pleased employee- about to hit 1 year mark
pros: Supportive Management team. Encourages education and resources to improve skills. Allows you to make recommendations and changes to policies openly, and will advise us on how to proceed or will assist us to come to an appropriate decision.
cons: None that are not manageable (gossipers, debbie-downers- few and far between!) . This truly is the best organization I have ever worked with!

pros: Great group of nurses! Most of the staff and nurses work well together.
cons: Compensation! You work more hours than you get paid for. Documentation is redundant, time consuming. Little to no continued education or training is offered. Nurses are often instructed to “google” something they are unfamiliar with. Follow up after hours is common and occurs almost daily. There are no resources for stressed out nurses.

pros: This is a Magnet hospital with a small-community feel. If you want to work somewhere where you won't feel like you are just a cog in the wheel, Middlesex is a place where you can really shine.
cons: As with most hospitals, the nursing shortage is always an issue. If you do not have your BSN, you probably won't get an interview, unless you are specialty-certified.

review_title: I prep and prepare food from recipes, also set up line for service and temp food for log book.
